results.title: Road to yesterday. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille, Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
This is a shortened version with music and commentary of Cecil B. De Mille’s elaborate 1925 romantic drama on the theme of reincarnation. An estranged couple are involved in a disastrous train crash and revert to their former lives in the Middle Ages. The train wreck was a remarkable piece of staging, placing the lives of the leading actors at risk.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cecil B. DeMille, Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: A Road in time
results.creator_credit: John Dick, Brian Bosisto, Brian Bosisto and Associates and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: With an eye to the energy crisis and environmental issues, this film gives a pictorial history of road-building in South Australia. As such, it also encapsulates the economic and urban development of this State. Contains b&w archival footage. Narrated by John Dick.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Dick, Brian Bosisto, Brian Bosisto and Associates and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Ritual in transfigured time
results.brief_description: An experimental film by Maya Deren illustrating what she describes as a critical metamorphosis, the changing of a widow into a bride. The process is not narrative or dramatic but choreographic. The attempt was to create a dance film, not only out of filmic time and space, as previously achieved in earlier films, but also out of non-dance elements. The dance quality is best expressed in the party scene: the party is treated as a choreographic pattern of movements. The final transformation of the widow in black to the bride in white is achieved by use of negative film, which reverses the values of the positive monotone. Photography by Helen Heyman; Choreography devised by Maya Deren and dancer Frank Westbrook; Principal performers are Rita Christiani and Frank Westbrook. Uncredited appearances by Maya Deren, Anais Nin and Gore Vidal.

results.title: Rhythm of Africa
results.brief_description: Cocteau uses much of the material of his earlier film “L’Amitie Noir”; it records the culture of the Chad people of French Equatorial Africa, showing the arts, the handicrafts, and some of their traditional ceremonial dances which have never before been recorded on film. Rarely heard songs and music, authentically recorded on the spot are another interesting feature of the film.

results.title: Renoir on Renoir
results.brief_description: Film director Jean Renoir talks about the work of his father Auguste Renoir, the important impressionist painter, and of their home Les Collettes Cagnes-sur-mer in the south of France. It is shot in the house and grounds of the home which Renoir the elder painted many times and which is now a museum. Many of Renoir’s great works are seen there. Interview by Huw Wheldon.

results.title: A Reason to read
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Studies the actions of students at three age levels- 5, 11 and 15 years and shows that in order to learn to read they must first want to read. It proposes that activities related to the teaching of reading should arise from the students own experience and interests, and that students should participate in the decision making concerning these activities. Features Croydon High, Enfield Junior and Gilles Street Primary schools.

results.title: The Puritan revolution: Cromwell and the rise of parliamentary democracy
results.creator_credit: Ken Hughes, Irving Allen, Columbia Pictures and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Shows how Parliament’s revolt, led by Cromwell and the puritans, erupts into full-scale civil war. When Charles is executed the absolute power of the monarchy ends and the nation is set on the road to parliamentary democracy. Specially edited from the film ‘Cromwell” starring Richard Harris as Cromwell and Alec Guiness as Charles I.

results.title: Prelude to war
results.creator_credit: Frank Capra and United States. War Dept.
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Why we fight”.
First in a series of documentaries made to acquaint soldiers with the causes and events leading up to the U.S.A.’s entry into World War II. This episode concentrates on the threat posed by the rise of German/Italian fascism and Japanese imperialism to world freedom. Narrated by John Huston. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Pesticides: friend or foe?
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Bruce Moir and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Shows the need for great care in the preparation and use of pesticides. A home gardener and a farmer each make many mistakes when spraying. Shows the mistakes, the dangerous results and the correct procedures.
